bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister reasonably believes that a woodlot licence holder has not met a requirement under section 35 [conforming to stocking standards] on an area, the minister may require the holder to carry out a survey to ascertain if the requirements have been met.
A woodlot licence holder must carry out a survey for the net area to be reforested, on or before the free growing date, identifying all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area for which the free growing stocking requirements have been met;
the number of healthy, well spaced free growing trees per hectare of preferred and acceptable species, as those species are described under section 35;
the number of healthy, well spaced free growing trees per hectare of the preferred species as those species are described under section 35;
for any areas for which the free growing stocking requirements have not been met, both the areas that are and are not satisfactorily stocked;
the forest cover inventory.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (3), the minister may exempt a woodlot licence holder from the requirement to carry out a free growing survey on an area if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister is satisfied that a free growing stand has been established on the area, and
the holder has provided the information referred to in subsection (3) (a) to (e) for that area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A woodlot licence holder who has carried out intermediate cuttings must carry out a survey, between 1 and 3 years after the completion of harvesting on the area, that identifies

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area,
the forest cover inventory, and
damage to trees by insects, disease or other factors affecting forest health.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Despite subsection (5), the minister may exempt a woodlot licence holder from the requirement to carry out a survey on an area of intermediate cuttings if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the area is too small to warrant the survey, or
the extent of harvesting does not significantly change the inventory label.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A woodlot licence holder must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: carry out other surveys and assessments according to the direction of the minister,
amend any survey or assessment prepared under this section, if required by the minister,
keep a record of each survey or assessment prepared under this section, and

provide a copy of the records under paragraph (c) to the minister when submitting the annual report for the year in which the survey or assessment was carried out, unless the minister requires the copy at a different time.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, reporting period, in respect of an annual report required under subsection (2), means the 12-month period that begins on January 1 of the year immediately preceding the year in which the annual report must be submitted.

A woodlot licence holder must, on or before May 31 each year, submit to the minister, in accordance with the requirements of subsections (3) and (4), an annual report respecting activities completed within the reporting period.
A woodlot licence holder must, unless the information was previously provided to the minister, include with an annual report the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a copy of any amendment made under section 20 (1) of the Act during the reporting period;

the approximate location of any resource feature or wildlife habitat feature, in or contiguous to a cutblock or road, that the holder became aware of during the reporting period, if the order establishing the resource feature or wildlife habitat feature requires the location of the resource feature or wildlife habitat feature to be included in the annual report required under subsection (2);
any other information specified by the chief forester.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The information required under subsection (3) (c) to be included in an annual report must be provided in an electronic format or another format satisfactory to the chief forester.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Exemptions and Relief from or Funding of Obligations

bcl:section.bcl:text: A woodlot licence holder is exempt from the requirements of section 21 (1) [compliance with plans] of the Act to the extent that results cannot be achieved or strategies cannot be carried out due to the actions of a person who has been authorized to act by the government.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister is satisfied that it is not practicable, given the circumstances or conditions applicable to a particular area, the minister may exempt a woodlot licence holder from

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: one or more of the following sections of the Act: 29; 29.1, or
one or more of the following sections of this regulation: 14; 15; 30; 31; 39 (3); 40 (2), (3) and (4); 41; 42; 43 to 52; 54; 56 (1); 59 to 62; 64; 65; 67; 68; 72 to 74.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may exempt a woodlot licence holder from section 29 (3) of the Act and section 34 or 35 of this regulation, in relation to a specific area, if all of the following apply:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the timber to be harvested is in danger of being significantly reduced in value, lost or destroyed;
the volume will not exceed 500 m3;
the area, when taken together with adjoining areas, will not result in a clearcut exceeding 1 ha, unless the adjoining area is occupied by a free growing stand.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exemptions by minister responsible for Wildlife Act

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister responsible for the Wildlife Act may exempt a person from section 55 of this regulation in relation to a general wildlife measure or section 55.1 of this regulation in relation to a general ecological community measure, if satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the intent of the general wildlife measure or general ecological community measure will be achieved, or
compliance with that provision is not practicable, given the circumstances or conditions applicable to a particular area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister responsible for the Wildlife Act may exempt a person from section 56 (2), 57 or 58 of this regulation if satisfied that compliance with that provision is not practicable, given the circumstances or conditions applicable to a particular area.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Relief from or Funding of Obligations

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Expenses incurred by a woodlot licence holder in carrying out measures under sections 26 (9) [control of insects, disease, animals or abiotic factors], 27 (5) [forest health emergency] and 77.1 (4) [power of intervention: first nations] of the Act must be paid by the government, if the minister is satisfied that the expenses were reasonably incurred.
For the purpose of section 77 (3) [power of intervention: general] of the Act, a woodlot licence holder may recover all or part of the amount reasonably incurred under that section if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the minister specifies in a notice under section 87 (1) [intervention orders] that the amount reasonably incurred in taking the required measures or actions is recoverable, and
the minister is satisfied that the amounts claimed by the holder were, in fact, reasonably incurred.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 29.1 (1) (b) or (3) (b) of the Act, a woodlot licence holder may transfer an obligation to establish a free growing stand if the minister is satisfied that the person to whom the obligation is to be transferred

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is likely to meet the obligation, and
has provided security to the minister in a form and in an amount specified by the minister.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister approves an agreement under section 29.1 (1) (c) or (3) (c) of the Act, the minister must return to the person who transferred the obligation any security deposit provided by that person specifically for that obligation.

Subject to subsections (4) and (5), the stocking standards referred to in section 29.1 (5) of the Act are the stocking standards that were in effect for the transferred obligation immediately before the transfer became effective.
The minister may approve stocking standards other than those referred to in subsection (3) if satisfied that the stocking standards are consistent with section 26.
A person to whom an obligation is transferred under section 29.1 of the Act must comply with Part 3 and section 75 of this regulation.
In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: affiliate has the same meaning as "affiliate" in section 53 [interpretation and application] of the Forest Act;

associated with means being associated with another person in a business activity whether by partnership, joint venture, contract or otherwise, and includes the contractual relationship between a licence holder and a person to whom the licence holder is contractually obliged to supply, directly or indirectly, some or all of the timber harvested under the licence holder's agreement;
control, with respect to a corporation, has the same meaning as "control of a corporation" in section 53 of the Forest Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 30 (1) (d) [free growing stands for non-replaceable licences] of the Act, a licence holder means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: does not hold a replaceable timber sale licence that has an allowable annual cut of greater than 10 000 m3, and
unless the minister is satisfied that it is in the public interest that this paragraph not apply,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: does not hold shares of any type in a corporation that holds

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a replaceable tree farm licence or forest licence, or
a replaceable timber sale licence that has an allowable annual cut greater than 10 000 m3,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is not affiliated with a corporation that holds shares of any type in

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a replaceable tree farm licence or forest licence, or
a replaceable timber sale licence that has an allowable annual cut greater than 10 000 m3, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is not associated with a holder of

bcl:clause.bcl:text: a replaceable tree farm licence or forest licence, or
a replaceable timber sale licence that has an allowable annual cut greater than 10 000 m3.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 30 (3) of the Act, the prescribed period for giving a notice under that section to a licence holder is one year.
For the purpose of section 30 (3) (d) of the Act, the following requirements must be met before a district manager may assume a licence holder's responsibility for establishing a free growing stand:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the licence holder requests that the district manager assume responsibility for establishing a free growing stand on all cutblocks that are harvested under the licence holder's agreement under the Forest Act, as and when the requirements referred to in section 30 (3) (a) to (c) of the Act are met in respect of those cutblocks;
the request referred to in paragraph (a) is made by the licence holder as part of the licence holder's first application for a cutting permit under the agreement under the Forest Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 108 (1) (b) [government may fund extra expense or waive obligation] of the Act, a woodlot licence holder must not be relieved from the requirements of section 26 [landslides], 27 [gully processes], 28 [natural surface drainage patterns] or 29 [revegetation], unless the minister is satisfied that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: extraordinary circumstances exist which, due to their nature, would make it unjust if the woodlot licence holder were not relieved, and
granting the relief is in the public interest.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 108 of the Act, an event causing damage, in relation to an area in which a person has an obligation to establish a free growing stand, means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an occurrence of wildfire,
an outbreak of dothiestroma, or
another event that renders the area ill-suited for the establishment of a free growing stand.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A woodlot licence holder claiming, under section 108 of the Act, relief from, or funding for, the obligation to establish a free growing stand, must provide to the minister the following information:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the nature of the relief sought and why the woodlot licence holder is entitled to it;
if the relief sought is funding under section 108 (4) of the Act, a proposal for returning the stand to the condition referred to in that subsection;
an estimate of the extra expense involved in carrying out the course of action, as described in section 108 (3) of the Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If the minister is satisfied that relief or funding is required, the minister must, within one year of receiving the information referred to in subsection (2),

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: grant the relief,
determine whether or not to provide the funds necessary for the proposal under subsection (2) (b), or
provide and fund an alternate course of action to that proposed under subsection (2) (b), if the minister determines that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the obligation to establish a free growing stand should continue, and
either

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the woodlot licence holder has not provided a proposed course of action under subsection (2) (b), or
the proposed course of action under subsection (2) (b) is unacceptable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: During the period of one year described in subsection (3), a person who makes a request is not required to meet a requirement of the Act or this regulation that relates to the request.

A woodlot licence holder may make a declaration under section 107 [limitation on liability of persons to government] of the Act that a free growing stand has been established on a cutblock at any time before the date referred to in section 34 [free growing stands] if the stand

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: has met the free growing height that relates to the area, and
is not under threat from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: competing plants, shrubs or other trees established on the area, or
insects, disease or other factors adverse to forest health in the area.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person may make a declaration under section 107 [limitation on liability of persons to government] of the Act in respect of a cutblock referred to in section 35 (2) [conforming to stocking standards] no earlier than 12 months after the completion of harvesting on the area.

A woodlot licence holder who makes a declaration under section 107 of the Act that the requirements for the regeneration date or free growing date on an area have been met must include with the declaration a forest cover inventory for the area to which the declaration applies.
The prescribed period for giving a notice to a woodlot licence holder under section 107 (3) of the Act is 15 months.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 585/2004, s. 18.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order or exemption under this regulation must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: be in writing,
specify the matter to which it relates,
specify when the order or exemption comes into effect,
be delivered to the woodlot licence holder to whom the order or exemption applies, and
be filed with the district office for the forest district in which the area or thing to which the order or exemption applies is located.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An order or exemption referred to in subsection (1) takes effect on the later of the date

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: specified in the order or exemption, or
the order or exemption is received by the woodlot licence holder to whom the order or exemption applies.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of subsection (2) (b), an order or exemption is received

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the date it is delivered, if it is delivered in person to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the woodlot licence holder to whom it applies or that holder's representative, or
the place of business of the woodlot licence holder to whom it applies,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: on the eighth day after it is mailed, if it is delivered by registered mail, or
on the date referred to in a confirmation of delivery, if it is delivered electronically or by facsimile transmission.

bcl:section.bcl:text: Repealed. [B.C. Reg. 585/2004, s. 18.]

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 77 (1) [power of intervention: general] of the Act, an order given by the minister must specify

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the measures or actions that must be taken,
the grounds for requiring the measures or actions to be taken, and
whether or not the holder may recover all or part of the amount reasonably incurred in taking the specified measures or actions.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The minister may act under section 77 (1) or (2) of the Act if the act or omission of the holder will likely result in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a significant failure in meeting the stocking requirements described in section 35 [conforming to stocking standards],
a significant delay in meeting the stocking requirements by the dates described in section 35, or
a fundamental and adverse alteration of an ecosystem.

bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purpose of section 71 (5) (g) [administrative penalties] of the Act, before levying an administrative penalty in respect of a contravention by a woodlot licence holder, the minister may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: request recommendations in respect of the contravention and penalty from any interested group, and
if a request under paragraph (a) is made, act on any recommendation received from the group to which the request was made.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes any of the following sections commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding $500 000 or to imprisonment for not more than 2 years or to both:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 24 (1) or (2) [soil disturbance limits];
section 26 [landslides];
section 34 (1) or (3) [free growing stands];
section 35 (2) [conforming to stocking standards];
section 41 [lakeshore management zones];
section 42 [temperature sensitive streams];
section 43 [stream crossings];
section 44 [fish passage];
section 45 [protection of fish and fish habitat];
section 46 [use of livestock in riparian areas];
section 47 [protecting water quality];
section 48 [licensed waterworks];
section 49 [excavated or bladed trails];
section 50 [roads in a community watershed];
section 51 (1) [use of fertilizers];
section 52 [wildlife tree retention];
section 53 [restriction on harvesting];
section 55 [general wildlife measures];
section 55.1 [general ecological community measures];
section 58 [water quality objectives];
section 61 [roads and associated structures];
section 62 [design of bridges];
section 63 (1) [peak flow];
section 64 [structural defects];
section 65 [culvert fabrication];
section 66 (1) (a) [retaining information];
section 68 (7) [road maintenance];
section 71 (1) (a), (b) or (c) [road deactivation];
section 72 [hazard warning];
section 87 (1) [intervention orders].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes any of the following sections commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding $100 000 or to imprisonment for not more than one year or to both:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 28 [natural surface drainage patterns];
section 29 [revegetation];
section 30 [modification of insect behaviour];
section 59 [visual quality objectives];
section 59.1 [visual quality: transition];
section 60 [recreation objectives];
section 66 (1) (b) or (c) or (3) [retaining information];
section 68 (1), (4) or (5) [road maintenance];
section 71 (1) (d) [road deactivation].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A person who contravenes any of the following sections commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to a fine not exceeding $5 000 or to imprisonment for not more than 6 months or to both:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: section 25 [permanent access structure limits];
section 31 [use of livestock];
section 32 (4) or (7) (b) [use of seed];
section 54 (1) [coarse woody debris];
section 66 (2) [retaining information];
section 67 [clearing widths];
section 68 (6) [road maintenance];
section 74 (1) [notification of timber harvesting and road construction].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a woodlot licence holder fails to comply with an alternative performance requirement for which the holder has received approval under section 13 [alternative performance requirements], the holder commits an offence and is liable, on conviction, to the fine or imprisonment, or both, that is applicable to the provision to which the alternative performance requirement relates.
Section 87 (2) [fines] of the Act does not apply to a woodlot licence holder who is liable under subsection (1).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Application of Code to forest development plans
bcl:section.bcl:text: The Code and the Code regulations apply to a forest development plan described in section 199 of the Act and to a forest development plan prepared under section 200 (1) of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Factors relating to land use objectives
bcl:section.bcl:text: Information contained in land use plans approved under the Land Act may be used as factors to determine if a woodlot licence plan is consistent with the objective described in section 9 (1) (e) [established objectives].
The following factors may be used for the purpose of developing a comprehensive wildlife tree retention strategy referred to in section 11 [wildlife tree retention strategy required]:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the size, structure, amount, location and other characteristics of trees that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: make the trees suitable for wildlife habitat, and
have ecological attributes that contribute to stand level biodiversity;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the extent to which wildlife habitat areas, ungulate winter ranges, riparian management zones, riparian reserve zones, scenic areas and other areas established to manage forest resources

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: provide suitable wildlife habitat, and
assist in the conservation of stand level biodiversity.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Factors relating to objective set by government for soils
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following factors may be used to determine if a woodlot licence plan is consistent with the objective set out in section 9 (1) (b) [established objectives]:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the amount of productive forest land base that will be occupied by permanent access structures;
the amount of soil disturbance within the net area to be reforested, having regard to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the classification of soils based on their biological, physical and chemical properties, including their sensitivity to displacement, surface erosion and compaction,
the kinds of disturbance that are detrimental to productivity and hydrological function,
the amount of detrimental disturbance that can occur without unduly compromising productivity or hydrological function, and
the extent to which rehabilitation efforts can mitigate the effects of detrimental disturbance.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Factors relating to water, fish, wildlife and biodiversity in riparian areas
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following factors may be used to determine if a woodlot licence plan is consistent with the objective set out in section 9 (1) (c) [established objectives]:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the type of management regime that is required for a riparian area, having regard to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the need to buffer the aquatic ecosystem of a stream, wetland or lake from the introduction of materials that are deleterious to water quality or fish habitat,
the role played by trees and understory vegetation in conserving water quality, fish habitat, wildlife habitat and biodiversity,
the need to maintain stream bank and stream channel integrity, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the type, timing or intensity of forest practices that can be carried out within the context of a management regime referred to in paragraph (a);
the role of forest shading in controlling an increase in temperature within a temperature sensitive stream, if the increase might have a deleterious effect on fish or fish habitat.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Factors relating to cultural heritage resources
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following factors may be used to determine if a woodlot licence plan is consistent with the objective set out in section 9 (1) (d) [established objectives]:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the relative value or importance of a particular cultural heritage resource to a traditional use by an aboriginal people;
the relative abundance or scarcity of a cultural heritage resource that is the focus of a traditional use by an aboriginal people;
the historical extent of a traditional use by an aboriginal people of a cultural heritage resource;
options for mitigating the impact that a forest practice might have on a cultural heritage resource that is the focus of a traditional use by an aboriginal people.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: even-aged stand means a stand of trees consisting of only one or two age classes;
uneven-aged stand means a stand of trees consisting of three or more age classes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following factors apply to the development of stocking standards generally:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the occurrence and extent of forest health factors.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following factors apply to the development of stocking standards under section 35 [conforming to stocking standards]:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for an area that is managed as an even-aged stand,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the types of commercially valuable and ecologically suitable species that should be established on the area, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for an area that is managed as an uneven-aged stand,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the factors referred to in paragraph (a) that are applicable to those parts of the area that will be reforested,
the types of commercially valuable and ecologically suitable species that should be retained on the area, and
the characteristics, quantity and distribution of retained trees referred to in subparagraph (ii).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following factors apply to developing stocking standards under section 12 [stocking information for specific areas]:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the types of commercially valuable and ecologically suitable species that should be retained on the area;
the characteristics, quantity and distribution of retained trees of a species referred to in paragraph (a) that are required to ensure the area will remain adequately stocked.
